articles.title: Leaders Talk About Peace in Ukraine
articles.summary: Donald Trump and Volodymyr Zelensky met in Florida to talk about ending the war in Ukraine. They said they made some progress, especially on security guarantees for Ukraine, which means the US might help protect Ukraine for 15 years. But they still have big problems to solve, like what will happen to the Donbas region. Russia wants to control all of Donbas, but Ukraine wants to keep some control. Both leaders think they are close to a peace deal, but they need to work more on the hard parts. They hope to stop the fighting soon.

articles.title: Kate Bush's Friend Missing at Sea
articles.summary: Kate Bush, a famous singer, is very sad because her good friend Matthew Upham went missing in the sea on Christmas Day. They were friends for 30 years. Matthew was a kind and fun person who loved swimming and kayaking. Emergency services searched for him in Budleigh Salterton, Devon, but had to stop. Kate shared her feelings on her website, saying Matthew was special and will be missed. His family is also heartbroken and thanked the rescuers for trying to help. This story shows how friends and family feel when someone they love is lost.

articles.title: Hospitals Face Big Problem with End-of-Life Care
articles.summary: Hospitals in Sussex, England, are having a hard time helping patients who are very sick and near the end of their lives. A doctor told other health leaders that there are too many end-of-life patients in hospital beds, which might stop other sick people from getting treatment this winter. Sometimes, these patients have to be cared for in emergency room corridors because there are not enough beds or places in hospices. The doctor said this is a crisis that is getting worse. Hospitals are trying to find better ways to care for these patients, like in community settings or hospices, so they don't have to stay in the hospital. This problem could happen in other areas too as winter brings more sick people to hospitals.

articles.title: A Dad Learns It's Okay to Ask for Help
articles.summary: Ryan Libbey, a former TV star, thought he could handle being a new dad, but things got tough. His partner had health problems after their baby was born, so Ryan had to take care of her and their son Leo all by himself. He did everything like feeding, changing diapers, and walking the baby, but after 11 months, he felt very tired and sad. One day, his dad talked to him on a park bench and said, 'You need help.' This made Ryan realize it's not weak to ask for help. Many dads feel this way but don't talk about it. Ryan learned that sharing feelings and getting support is important for dads too, so they can be happy and help their families.

articles.title: Guinea's First Election After a Coup
articles.summary: Guinea, a country in Africa, held an election on Sunday to choose a new president. This was the first election since a coup in 2021, when the military took over. The junta leader, General Mamadi Doumbouya, is likely to win because the opposition is weak. Guinea has many minerals like bauxite, but many people are poor and hungry. Young people hope the election will bring better jobs and life. Voting was mostly smooth, but some people boycotted it. The results will come soon, and if no one gets most votes, there will be another round. This election is part of a new rule that lets military leaders run and makes the president's term longer.

articles.title: Kosovo's Prime Minister Wins Big in Early Election
articles.summary: In Kosovo, a country in Europe, Prime Minister Albin Kurti's party won a big victory in an early election. The election happened on Sunday, and his party, called Vetevendosje, got almost half of all votes. This means he will likely stay as prime minister. The election was called early because his party could not form a government after another election in February, which caused a long delay. Kurti said they have a lot of work to do now. Supporters celebrated in the capital city, Pristina. Kosovo is a young country that became independent from Serbia in 2008 after a war. The country has not approved a budget for next year, which worries people about the economy. About 44% of voters turned out to vote.
